user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
```c
bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
{
    OS_creator_filter_t *filter = ref;

    /*
     * Check if the obj_id is both valid and matches
     * the specified creator_id
     */
    return (OS_ObjectIdIsValid(obj->active_id) && (OS_ObjectIdEqual(filter->creator_id, OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY) ||
                                                   OS_ObjectIdEqual(obj->creator, filter->creator_id)));
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function OS_ForEachFilterCreator:
typedef struct
{
    osal_id_t        creator_id;
    OS_ArgCallback_t user_callback;
    void *           user_arg;
} OS_creator_filter_t
...
typedef struct OS_common_record OS_common_record_t
...
typedef struct OS_object_token OS_object_token_t
...
#define OS_OBJECT_CREATOR_ANY OS_OBJECT_ID_UNDEFINED
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags: bool OS_ForEachFilterCreator(void *ref, const OS_object_token_t *token, const OS_common_record_t *obj)
explanation: Other fragments need not be investigated for Rule 17.8 because they do not modify function parameters: - The token and obj parameters are declared const and are only dereferenced for reads (obj->active_id, obj->creator), so no modification of the pointer parameters or pointed-to objects occurs in the shown code. - There are no assignments to the parameter variables (ref, token, obj) elsewhere in the function body. - The comment and surrounding whitespace/typedef/macro definitions do not affect parameter modification. - Calls to the helper functions/macros shown (OS_ObjectIdIsValid, OS_ObjectIdEqual) are used in boolean expressions only; based on the presented code there is no evidence they modify the passed-in parameters here. If those helper functions have side effects, they should be reviewed separately, but they are outside the provided fragment.
